852.text: so in terms of the completion rate is there are two steps in how that's calculated.

858.text: The first step is what they call the contract completion,

891.text: So from that analysis data let's say, start with a contract completion,

896.text: add a recommencement rate to get what they call the individual completion rate,

900.text: which is trying to focus on what's the overall completion rate of an apprentice

1989.text: and the range of work and engagement with students, parents, career advisor's et cetera,

1995.text: to try and get a better pool of well-informed apprentices with strong vocational interests who are most likely to complete.

2001.text: What we found in talking to the apprentices was that the ones who knew exactly what they were coming into,

2007.text: had a real interest in the trade - possibly because their father or an uncle or family friend was in the trade

2013.text: and they knew exactly what the trade was about and were therefore motivated -

2021.text: So what we're talking about doing here is actually trying to, if you like,

2025.text: build up a bigger pool of potential applicants from whom employers could choose.

2030.text: Because again, the good employers we chose from,

2033.text: the place I mentioned out in Melbourne, WD Adams, they get I think,

2037.text: I can't remember the exact numbers, but it's something like 15 apprentices

2045.text: So they're actually able to draw from a very wide range of pools,

2048.text: compared to other employers we spoke to who are basically saying,

2051.text: well we kind of take what we can get.

2053.text: So the variation between that organisation and others was significant.

2058.text: We do see an important role to re-think the role of the Australian Apprenticeship Centres,

2064.text: to have a more active role in assisting employers, rather than just being transactional.

2072.text: I've spoken about the advisory services,

2074.text: what we also found was that the Australian Apprenticeship Mentoring Program that was established

2081.text: I think two or three years ago, of all the programs that were mentioned -

2088.text: and we found the same thing by the way in the Building Australia's Future Workforce study -

2093.text: the mentoring one gets a really big tick.

2096.text: That's both from the point of the view of the organisations who are running it,

2100.text: from RTOs and group schemes but also from the individual employers.

2105.text: What it means is that, the way the mentors work,

2108.text: it basically means that a lot of the sharp edges that can occur

2114.text: when the relationship between an apprentice and employer starts to deteriorate,

2119.text: a lot of the mentors are older, they're experienced, they've been through it

2124.text: and they can come in and be a bit of a neutral party to help resolve some of those issues.

2129.text: It seems to be particularly important for young apprentices who don't really have anywhere else to go,

2134.text: their families mightn't know, can't give the advice,

2137.text: the RTOs aren't that highly engaged in what's happening in the workplace

2141.text: and of course they're a bit scared to talk to the boss, so the mentoring programs got a big tick.

2149.text: What we found was that training quality wasn't identified as a significant factor in apprenticeship non-completions.

2162.text: That's not to say that training quality was uniformly brilliant but it's just that it wasn't -

2167.text: because your TAFE or your private RTO isn't providing quite the quality of training that you might have expected,

2174.text: it's not actually forcing people to drop out.

2175.text: What it may mean is that they would switch RTO to go somewhere else.

2180.text: It's not ideal but it doesn't seem to be a major factor in non-completions.

2185.text: But, in terms of learning support for disability, low levels of language, literacy and numeracy

2193.text: and, if you're going to target anything in terms of the activities of RTOs it would be in that area.

2200.text: Because what it means is that apprentices who aren't aware of the complexity of what they're getting into,

2206.text: who don't have good literacy skills, who start with the employer and then they hit TAFE or hit the RTO,

2213.text: then find over time that their literacy skills aren't adequate to make it through.

2219.text: Certainly, anecdotally, and certainly if you look at NAPLAN and other things

2223.text: there is certainly evidence about declining literacy in the pool of apprentices coming through.

2228.text: So the need for continuing focus on literacy

2233.text: within the formal training program structure was also important.

2240.text: We'll wait and see what happens with the Fair Work Australia wage decision.

2247.text: We asked and we got very different views, even from employers.

2254.text: Some employers were saying wages were too low, we're happy to pay the extra,

2257.text: we'll get better kids and we're just going to swallow it and get on with it.

2260.text: Others - group training organisations were really worried in terms of the impact on their charge out rates.

2266.text: It may play a role in attracting high quality candidates

2270.text: and therefore getting better candidates meaning that retention rates go up,

2275.text: but it could also lead to some employers,

2278.text: particularly ones who are facing a lot of cost and competitive pressures,

2282.text: cancelling contracts or opting not to take new apprentices on.

2287.text: As the point says, the consultations indicated wage levels are not a significant factor in non-completions

2295.text: and that's because apprentices are reasonably aware of what they're going to get into

2299.text: but again I'd just add my comment there about the age factor.

2303.text: So I think that's basically a bit of a wait and see one, to see what happens,

2307.text: although it might be hard to disentangle the impact of the wage decisions from the general economic conditions.

2313.text: Then, I won't go through all of this in detail,

2318.text: but basically we've looked at the bodies that would be responsible

2322.text: for implementing the range of strategies that we've put in paper and the resource implications.

2330.text: I think our general view is that a lot of this doesn't require a massive injection of resources,

2335.text: it just requires a re-focussing of roles, a stronger emphasis of roles in some areas,

2340.text: a continuation of some programs, or a possible expansion of them.

2345.text: But particularly better coordination between the Australian Apprenticeship Centres

2349.text: and the state training authorities at the front end and then during the process.
